greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Square array A(n,k), n>=0, k>=0, read by antidiagonals, where sequence a_k of column k is the exponential transform of C(n,k).
comment: A(n,k) is also the number of ways of placing n labeled balls into indistinguishable boxes, where in each filled box k balls are seen at the top. E.g. A(3,1)=10:
link: Alois P. Heinz, Antidiagonals n = 0..140, flattened
formula: A(0,k) = 1 and A(n,k) = Sum_{i=0..n-1} binomial(n-1,i) * binomial(i+1,k) * A(n-1-i,k) for n > 0. - _Seiichi Manyama_, Sep 28 2017
mathematica: Exptr[p_] := Module[{g}, g[n_] := g[n] = If[n == 0, 1, Sum[Binomial[n-1, j-1] *p[j]*g[n-j], {j, 1, n}]]; g]; A[n_, k_] := Exptr[Function[i, Binomial[i, k]]][n]; Table[Table[A[n, d-n], {n, 0, d}], {d, 0, 12}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jan 15 2014, translated from Maple *)
program: (1..n).each{|i| ary << (0..i - 1).inject(0){|s, j| s + ncr(i - 1, j) * ncr(j + 1, k) * ary[i - 1 - j]}}
results.author: _Alois P. Heinz_, Oct 10 2008
